quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In my conversation with Sanchan, we cover what he's learned from working with some of today's best CEOs, including Brian Chesky, Brian Armstrong, Zuck and Kevin Systrom, what it was like inside Airbnb when COVID hit and how they made it through travel completely stopping, how to set up your product development process at a startup, tips for hiring amazing product managers, when to hire your first PM, when to A/B test and when not to, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A dense preview of practical topics—startup product process, hiring, and experimentation decisions—that practitioners can directly apply.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So many product managers are basically treated like project managers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a common organizational anti-pattern that can limit PM impact and signals a need to clarify the PM role.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You get higher thinking that you'll be deep in product strategy and vision, and getting to know your customers, only to wind up organizing other people's work and finding backlogs and optimizing tiny, tiny features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable warning about role drift—useful for PMs to diagnose mis-scoped responsibilities and reset expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So many product managers are basically treated like project managers.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Kansal
quotes.context: Highlights a common role trap PMs can watch for and actively push back against by refocusing on product thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You get higher thinking that you'll be deep in product strategy and vision, and getting to know your customers, only to wind up organizing other people's work and finding backlogs and optimizing tiny, tiny features.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Kansal
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of how PM work can drift into low-leverage execution, useful for diagnosing mis-scoped responsibilities.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Because Dovetail gets that the true heart of product management is understanding what customers want, why they want it and how to give it to them.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Kansal
quotes.context: Offers a simple mental model for PM priorities: customer desires, underlying motivations, and delivery mechanisms.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Dovetail offers a suite of powerful analysis tools to help you identify themes, patterns and insights in your customer interviews, allowing you to make better, data informed decisions about what solutions you should build next.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Kansal
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to systematize qualitative research into themes and patterns to drive build-next decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can integrate Persona in an afternoon and personalize your flows using their SDK to meet your users on any device.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Kansal
quotes.context: A concrete implementation claim that sets an execution benchmark for adding identity/KYC flows quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sanchan’s path into product management
quotes.text: I started in engineering. But within a year or so, I moved into product.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Highlights a practical path into PM: start adjacent (engineering) and transition quickly once you find the fit.

quotes.topic_title: Sanchan’s path into product management
quotes.text: And fun fact, when I joined Instagram, it was still very small. And it was less than, I think, 50 engineers or something like that. Very tiny. It was pre-revenue. We made $0 in revenue.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A concrete example that high-impact product careers can come from joining early-stage teams before revenue exists.

quotes.topic_title: Sanchan’s path into product management
quotes.text: I was a GM of Airbnb Plus, but also the head of product helping Brian Chesky scale the product management organization, establish the culture of it, and see how best we can build a world class part organization.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Shows a scalable PM leadership model: combine business ownership with org/culture building to multiply impact.

quotes.topic_title: Sanchan’s path into product management
quotes.text: But then the more I read, the more I realized, "Man, this is one of the biggest revolutions happening."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Captures a repeatable decision heuristic: deep research can convert passive interest into conviction to build.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: little bets and learning fast
quotes.text: My biggest advice to people is, oftentimes the analysis paralysis of dotting every eye, crossing every tee sometimes chokes you out of opportunities. When you find something that gives you energy, just jump in with both feet.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to prioritize momentum over over-planning and act quickly when you find energizing work.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: little bets and learning fast
quotes.text: That's how you would create a great career as opposed to sort of a five year career plan and working backwards from that. Those things just don't work.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Contrarian take that challenges rigid long-term career planning in favor of iterative exploration.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: little bets and learning fast
quotes.text: You take little bets, you try them out. If they don't work out, you build rapid recovery and start to do something else.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable career methodology: experiment small, recover fast, and iterate.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: little bets and learning fast
quotes.text: If you become too scientific, you miss out on opportunities because you can't see those opportunities using the scientific method of discovery, because they're too tiny or they're so farfetched that people cannot even understand them.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Memorable warning about over-indexing on rigor in product work and missing high-upside, non-obvious bets.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice: little bets and learning fast
quotes.text: My advice to people is go get a job which will make you the fastest learner in the field of product management.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A clear decision rule for choosing roles: optimize for learning velocity over brand, title, or credentials.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing startups vs big companies to learn
quotes.text: The way to think about this is let's say you want to get to a destination, whichever destination it is, you probably want to get on the faster ship. You don't want to get on a slower ship.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for choosing a company environment that accelerates your path to a specific career goal.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing startups vs big companies to learn
quotes.text: There are three types of learning, a starter learning, meaning you can get started. You're a person who can get started. You see an idea, you see an opportunity, you can get started. Right?
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Introduces a practical learning-mode taxonomy to help people match roles/companies to how they grow.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing startups vs big companies to learn
quotes.text: And there's zero to one people who can then take what they have started and scale it to one. And then there are one and beyond people who are scalers, who will scale the system that is found product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Extends the framework into distinct execution strengths (0→1 vs 1→N) that imply different best-fit company stages.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing startups vs big companies to learn
quotes.text: I've seen many successful leaders who will get choked up in a big company environment, and I've seen many big company successful executives who want to choke up in a very startup environment. And this is not for everybody. Both sides of the games are not for everybody.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that “best place to learn” is highly individual and that success in one environment may not transfer.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing startups vs big companies to learn
quotes.text: First and foremost recognizing what gives you energy, recognizing where you thrive the most is really important.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to optimize career decisions around personal energy and fit, not just prestige or conventional wisdom.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airbnb was his biggest learning experience
quotes.text: The product of Airbnb isn't the app. It is a means to an end. The product of Airbnb is the memories you're going to create when you sit in that Airbnb beautiful house with your family, with your friends, and you're building those memories. That's the product. It's in real world.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for defining the “real” product as the user’s outcome, not the software interface.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airbnb was his biggest learning experience
quotes.text: And how you build a real world product which is of course powered by software, like the app, the website, et cetera, is different than just building a pure product that is purely software.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable distinction for practitioners building marketplaces/experiences: software is only one component of the product system.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airbnb was his biggest learning experience
quotes.text: I tell my friends I could not have gone to HBS Stanford business school to learn crisis management as much as I learned while being in the front row seat managing through that.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A contrarian take that real crises can be a higher-fidelity leadership training ground than formal education.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airbnb was his biggest learning experience
quotes.text: My learning as a product leader from Brian as a hyperscaler, taking the product management organization from 30, 40 people to 200 people, and last but not the least, managing the crisis. I felt like it all compressed into three years something that you will learn in 30.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Concrete scaling data plus a “compressed learning” framing for evaluating high-growth roles and environments.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airbnb was his biggest learning experience
quotes.text: Oftentimes you meet leaders who are leaving Facebook, Amazon, Google, and it's like, "Hey, here's my Excel spreadsheet. Here's how I imagine the startup that I'm joining will grow. Here's the valuation. Here's my life. Here's my compensation. That's it." None of that shit is going to happen.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A blunt warning against over-planning career/startup trajectories and assuming predictable growth paths.

quotes.topic_title: Inside Airbnb’s COVID crisis and turnaround
quotes.text: Look, can't plan for a year, can't plan for a quarter. We're going to plan every two weeks. We're going to react to every two weeks.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence for high-uncertainty environments: shorten planning horizons and build a rhythm of rapid re-evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Inside Airbnb’s COVID crisis and turnaround
quotes.text: The real genius isn't to dot every eye, to cross every team before you get started. The real genius is, what do you do when shit goes wrong?
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Reframes “good execution” away from perfect upfront planning toward resilience and response under failure conditions.

quotes.topic_title: Inside Airbnb’s COVID crisis and turnaround
quotes.text: I believe rapid recovery is the key to success. What you do, how quickly you can recover from failure becomes really important.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A memorable mental model emphasizing recovery speed as a core capability, not just avoiding mistakes.

quotes.topic_title: Inside Airbnb’s COVID crisis and turnaround
quotes.text: Our operating model changed. We went to two weeks shipping. All right, what are we doing for the next two weeks? What is the most urgent thing for the company? For the company. Not my team, not your team, not somebody else's team.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A practical prioritization rule for crisis execution: optimize for company-level urgency and ship in tight increments.

quotes.topic_title: Inside Airbnb’s COVID crisis and turnaround
quotes.text: There's a very good saying, which is, you can have all the plan. The moment you step inside the boxing and you get a punch on your face, all your plans go out the window. And you got to stay calm when you get a punch on your face.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A vivid crisis-leadership heuristic: expect plans to break on contact with reality and prioritize composure under pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Two-week planning mechanics and morale building
quotes.text: And so there was a mixture of top-down guidance to a bottoms-up things that we are seeing on the field. And every two weeks or so, the leadership, Greg in that case, for example, would make a decision on, "Here are the things we are going to go handle."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A practical biweekly execution model that combines top-down mandates with frontline customer signals to decide priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Two-week planning mechanics and morale building
quotes.text: We basically dissolved this idea that there are sub-teams. There was one team, #Airbnb. Didn't matter whether you worked in CX or Airbnb Plus or Lax, or any of those things, we're going to move engineers wherever we have to, we're going to move PMs wherever we need to, and there's no such thing as sub-team anymore.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A crisis operating mode: remove org boundaries and redeploy talent fluidly to the highest-survival priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Two-week planning mechanics and morale building
quotes.text: The most honest answer you can tell them is, "I don't know." Because if you cook shit up, they're going to see through that lie. They're going to like, "Ah, this is just all marketing fluff."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Counterintuitive leadership guidance: admitting uncertainty can build more trust than forced certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Two-week planning mechanics and morale building
quotes.text: We had to get people from feature obsession, revenue obsession, to belief obsession.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A memorable reframe for morale and focus during existential uncertainty—anchor teams in shared beliefs rather than metrics alone.

quotes.topic_title: Two-week planning mechanics and morale building
quotes.text: For example, there was a survey we did, we said, "If money wasn't a consideration, what would you do for the rest of your life?" 99.99% of the people said, "I will travel the world."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A concrete data point used as evidence-based storytelling to reinforce conviction in the long-term mission.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Product leaders trust Productboard to help their teams build products that matter.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear product leadership principle: optimize for building what matters (outcomes), not just shipping features.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: From startups to industry titans, over 6,000 companies rely on Productboard to get the right products to market faster, including companies like Zoom, Volkswagen, UiPath and Vanguard.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete adoption data and recognizable examples that signal the approach/tool scales across company sizes and industries.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Productboard can help you create a scalable, transparent and standardized process, so your PMs understand what their customers really need and then prioritize the right features to build next.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An actionable methodology: standardize discovery-to-prioritization so customer needs directly drive what gets built next.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Stakeholders feel the love two with an easy to view roadmap that automatically updates so everyone knows what you're building and why.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Practical stakeholder-management tactic: keep an auto-updating roadmap to align teams on both the what and the why.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Make data-driven product decisions that result in higher revenue and user adoption, and empower your product teams to create delightful customer experiences.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable outcomes chain linking data-driven decisions to business metrics and customer experience quality.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: simplicity, intentionality, and Stories
quotes.text: The thing that I learned from Kevin Systrom was the power of simplicity. That guy can listen to everything, hear everything, hear the noise on Twitter, here, there, all the customers complaining, and then just simplify things that makes sense for the team to operate on. That's his superpower, which is simplicity. Take all the information, but simplify your strategy, your belief, who you want to be when you grow up in a way that people can then act on it.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A practical leadership model: absorb broad input, then distill it into a simple strategy the team can execute.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: simplicity, intentionality, and Stories
quotes.text: On Instagram side, Kevin Systrom made a decision. We're going all in on this new format. There was no A/B testing that if you add stories at the top ...
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example of committing to a major product bet without waiting for exhaustive experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: simplicity, intentionality, and Stories
quotes.text: The founder said, "We're going all in people. This is the future. We're not going to measure and then cut. We're going to cut. And then we are going to iterate from that new baseline. We're going to continue to iterate on that on the Facebook side."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A memorable methodology for big shifts: set a new baseline first, then iterate—rather than letting metrics block the change.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: simplicity, intentionality, and Stories
quotes.text: First tell me the intentionality of the product that you want to create. What do you want to see come true? And then let's talk about the A/B test we can run to measure that we are headed in the right direction.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for product work: define the intended end state before designing experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Founder lessons: simplicity, intentionality, and Stories
quotes.text: The other thing I learned with Brian Chesky was you first want to create an ideal end state of the product without any constraint.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A reusable design framework: start unconstrained with the ideal end state, then work backward to reality.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb product philosophy: 15/10 vision then scale
quotes.text: Do you have any thoughts for someone trying to decide how do I know if I'm going in the right direction, how do I know if I should trust this gut that I have versus running A/B test, because otherwise we don't know?
quotes.speaker: Sachin Kansal
quotes.context: Frames the core practitioner dilemma of intuition vs. experimentation when deciding product direction.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb product philosophy: 15/10 vision then scale
quotes.text: Do you have any thoughts on that?
quotes.speaker: Sachin Kansal
quotes.context: Invites a concrete decision-making heuristic or methodology to resolve the intuition vs. A/B testing tradeoff.

quotes.topic_title: When to trust gut vs data and A/B tests
quotes.text: You never go into your car and say, "Hey, GPS, tell me where I should go."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for separating vision/intentionality (destination) from optimization (route/testing).

quotes.topic_title: When to trust gut vs data and A/B tests
quotes.text: And to me, gut and intuition is data. It's just not statistically significant yet.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Reframes intuition as an early signal practitioners should respect while they work toward validation.

quotes.topic_title: When to trust gut vs data and A/B tests
quotes.text: He used to say, "You got to have impatience with getting started, but patience for seeing them through."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on execution cadence: start fast, then persist long enough to realize non-obvious ideas.

quotes.topic_title: When to trust gut vs data and A/B tests
quotes.text: Build a culture in your team where failure of those experiments is actually celebrated.
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A concrete cultural prescription for increasing learning velocity and reducing fear-driven decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: When to trust gut vs data and A/B tests
quotes.text: And Kevin Systrom says, "No, my intentionality is that story should be real time news. It should be the world's largest TV channel. You open that up and you see what's happening right now. That is the intentionality I'm going towards."
quotes.speaker: Sanchan Saxena
quotes.context: A specific example of vision overriding research/data to preserve a product’s intended behavior and positioning.
